title: Anomaly-outlier detection DBSCAN labels for scatter plot

yaml.title: Anomaly-outlier detection DBSCAN labels for scatter plot
yaml.author: Heba Nusair

markdown.headingText: Load the data - make sure this path is correct
markdown.markdown:
```{python}

from sklearn.cluster import DBSCAN
from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler
from sklearn.neighbors import NearestNeighbors
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

df = pd.read_csv('Homeplaces in Roanoke and Salem Cities.csv')

# Select only the geographic coordinates
df_geo = df[['X', 'Y']]

# Standardizing the features (important for K-Means)
scaler = StandardScaler()
df_geo_scaled = scaler.fit_transform(df_geo)

# Assuming you have already standardized your data and have df_geo_scaled ready

# Plot the k-distance graph again with a zoomed-in scale if necessary
nbrs = NearestNeighbors(n_neighbors=4).fit(df_geo_scaled)
distances, indices = nbrs.kneighbors(df_geo_scaled)

# Sort the distances and plot them
distances = np.sort(distances, axis=0)
distances = distances[:, 3-1]
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 6))
plt.plot(distances)
plt.title('k-distance Graph')
plt.xlabel('Point index')
plt.ylabel('Distance to 3rd nearest neighbor')
plt.show()

# Adjust these values based on your domain knowledge and previous results
eps_value = 0.05  # Decrease if you want more, smaller clusters
min_samples_value = 15  # Increase if you want fewer, denser clusters

# Perform DBSCAN clustering with the adjusted parameters
dbscan = DBSCAN(eps=eps_value, min_samples=min_samples_value)
clusters = dbscan.fit_predict(df_geo_scaled)

# Add cluster labels to the dataframe
df['Cluster'] = clusters

# Plot the clusters with the adjusted parameters
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
scatter = plt.scatter(df['X'], df['Y'], c=df['Cluster'], cmap='viridis', marker='o')
plt.title('DBSCAN Clustering of Homeplaces in Roanoke and Salem Cities with Adjusted Parameters')
plt.xlabel('Longitude')
plt.ylabel('Latitude')
colorbar = plt.colorbar(scatter, label='Cluster Label')
plt.show()

```
markdown.srcMarkdownNoYaml:
```{python}

from sklearn.cluster import DBSCAN
from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler
from sklearn.neighbors import NearestNeighbors
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Load the data - make sure this path is correct
df = pd.read_csv('Homeplaces in Roanoke and Salem Cities.csv')

# Select only the geographic coordinates
df_geo = df[['X', 'Y']]

# Standardizing the features (important for K-Means)
scaler = StandardScaler()
df_geo_scaled = scaler.fit_transform(df_geo)

# Assuming you have already standardized your data and have df_geo_scaled ready

# Plot the k-distance graph again with a zoomed-in scale if necessary
nbrs = NearestNeighbors(n_neighbors=4).fit(df_geo_scaled)
distances, indices = nbrs.kneighbors(df_geo_scaled)

# Sort the distances and plot them
distances = np.sort(distances, axis=0)
distances = distances[:, 3-1]
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 6))
plt.plot(distances)
plt.title('k-distance Graph')
plt.xlabel('Point index')
plt.ylabel('Distance to 3rd nearest neighbor')
plt.show()

# Adjust these values based on your domain knowledge and previous results
eps_value = 0.05  # Decrease if you want more, smaller clusters
min_samples_value = 15  # Increase if you want fewer, denser clusters

# Perform DBSCAN clustering with the adjusted parameters
dbscan = DBSCAN(eps=eps_value, min_samples=min_samples_value)
clusters = dbscan.fit_predict(df_geo_scaled)

# Add cluster labels to the dataframe
df['Cluster'] = clusters

# Plot the clusters with the adjusted parameters
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
scatter = plt.scatter(df['X'], df['Y'], c=df['Cluster'], cmap='viridis', marker='o')
plt.title('DBSCAN Clustering of Homeplaces in Roanoke and Salem Cities with Adjusted Parameters')
plt.xlabel('Longitude')
plt.ylabel('Latitude')
colorbar = plt.colorbar(scatter, label='Cluster Label')
plt.show()

```
